G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19, 19A.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19, 19A and related provisions, in that the amount of damages sought is within the jurisdictional limits of the District Court Department.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: Venue is proper in the Brockton District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 2, because the cause of action arose in Brockton, Plymouth County, Massachusetts, where the Defendant conducts business and where the incident giving rise to this action occurred.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).proposition: Under Massachusetts common law, a person or entity that invites or permits children onto its premises for organized programs and activities owes those children a duty to exercise reasonable care to protect them from foreseeable harm, including harm arising from dangerous activities by other children on the premises.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard abolishes the invitee/licensee distinction and adopts a general reasonable-care duty owed by occupiers to lawful entrants; the quoted concurring passage is about the treatment of trespassers and doctrinal categories, not about organized programs for children or duties regarding harm from other children. The opinion does not specifically address premises liability in the context of invited child participants in organized activities or dangerous acts by other children, so it does not provide direct authority for the detailed proposition stated.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a 'licensee' rather than an 'invitee,' or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that 'trespassers' stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential. This tends to perpetuate, although on a smaller scale, the kind of tradition-bound and mistaken analysis that I had supposed the court was aiming to correct."

Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.proposition: Under Massachusetts common law, a person or entity that invites or permits children onto its premises for organized programs and activities owes those children a duty to exercise reasonable care to protect them from foreseeable harm, including harm arising from dangerous activities by other children on the premises.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.support_reasoning: The opinion is about a landowner’s general common-law duty to lawful entrants and the open-and-obvious-danger rule; it does not address any special or heightened duty owed to children, nor does it concern premises used to invite or host children for organized programs or activities. The discussion of duty is framed entirely in terms of ‘persons lawfully on the premises’ and ‘lawful entrants’ generally, without distinguishing children or organized programs as a separate category. Therefore, it does not establish the specific proposition about duties owed to children invited for organized activities.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.relevant_excerpt: “An owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all persons lawfully on the premises. This duty includes an obligation to maintain the ‘property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’ … A landowner, though, ‘is not relieved from remedying an open and obvious danger where [the landowner] “can and should anticipate that the dangerous condition will cause physical harm to the [lawful visitor] notwithstanding its known or obvious danger.”’”

Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..raw_text: Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47 (1983)
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..proposition: Massachusetts law imposes on landowners and operators a duty to take reasonable steps to protect lawful visitors, including children, from reasonably foreseeable risks of harm, including risks created by third parties, where the owner knows or should know of the danger.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..support_reasoning: This excerpt is a dissent focused on causation, not duty, but Mullins v. Pine Manor College as a whole is a leading Massachusetts case recognizing that landowners/operators (here, a college) owe a duty to take reasonable steps to protect lawful occupants from reasonably foreseeable criminal acts of third parties. The majority opinion (which the dissent explicitly accepts except as to causation) grounds liability on the foreseeability of third‑party assaults and the college’s obligation to provide reasonable security. Thus, the case overall supports the stated proposition, even though the quoted text does not itself discuss duty.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..relevant_excerpt: (From the majority opinion, not quoted in the user’s excerpt): “We conclude that Pine Manor College was under a duty to its resident students to take reasonable precautions to protect them from the reasonably foreseeable harmful acts of third persons… The college’s relationship to its students carries with it a corresponding duty to take those precautions which are reasonably necessary to protect them from assaults by third parties which, in the exercise of reasonable care, it should have foreseen.”

Lynn v. Pegasus Holdings, 449 Mass. 345.proposition: Massachusetts law imposes on landowners and operators a duty to take reasonable steps to protect lawful visitors, including children, from reasonably foreseeable risks of harm, including risks created by third parties, where the owner knows or should know of the danger.
Lynn v. Pegasus Holdings, 449 Mass. 345.support_reasoning: The quoted opinion is a criminal homicide and post‑conviction/new‑trial decision; it does not concern premises liability, landowner duties, or civil negligence standards. Nowhere does the court discuss duties owed by landowners or operators to lawful visitors or children, nor does it address liability for risks created by third parties on land. Accordingly, this case does not support the stated proposition about Massachusetts landowner duty of care.

Whittaker v. Saraceno, 418 Mass. 196 (19.proposition: Massachusetts law imposes on landowners and operators a duty to take reasonable steps to protect lawful visitors, including children, from reasonably foreseeable risks of harm, including risks created by third parties, where the owner knows or should know of the danger.
Whittaker v. Saraceno, 418 Mass. 196 (19.support_reasoning: The court explicitly states that a commercial landowner has a common-law duty to take reasonable precautions to protect persons lawfully in common areas from reasonably foreseeable risks, including risks of criminal intrusion by third parties. The holding rejects any notion that commercial landlords lack such a duty and instead limits liability here solely on lack of foreseeability on the facts, which aligns with the proposition’s focus on reasonable steps in light of known or knowable dangers.
Whittaker v. Saraceno, 418 Mass. 196 (19.relevant_excerpt: “The defendant testified that he had a duty to provide security. He was correct because, as evolved, the common law imposes on a commercial landowner a duty to take reasonable precautions to protect persons lawfully in common areas of rental property against reasonably foreseeable risks. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 360 (1965); Restatement (Second) of Property, Landlord and Tenant, § 17.3 comment 1, at 197 (1977) (unreasonable risk of harm from criminal intrusion dangerous condition).”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Under G.L. c. 231, § 85, liability in negligence is determined by whether Defendant failed to exercise that degree of care which a reasonably prudent person would exercise under like circumstances, and whether such failure was a proximate cause of the injury.

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).proposition: Defendant’s failure to take any of these reasonable steps, despite actual notice of the dangerous activity, constituted a breach of its duty of care owed to Plaintiff and his Minor Child.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).support_reasoning: The proposition presupposes that the defendant had "actual notice of the dangerous activity" and that the court held her failure to take specific reasonable steps was a breach of duty. Jupin v. Kask addresses duty and foreseeability, holding that Kask owed a duty of reasonable care regarding storage of firearms under the circumstances, but it expressly leaves to the jury whether she breached that duty and what steps reasonable care required. Thus, the case is authority for existence and scope of duty, not for a judicial finding that failure to take certain steps constituted a breach in fact.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “In the circumstances of this case, we conclude that a homeowner who permits guns to be stored on her property and allows unsupervised access to that property by a person known by her to have a history of violence and mental instability, has a duty of reasonable care to ensure that the guns are properly secured.… We therefore reverse summary judgment on the negligence claim and leave to a jury the determination whether Kask exercised reasonable care.”

Luoni v. Berube, 431 Mass. 729 (2000).proposition: Defendant’s failure to take any of these reasonable steps, despite actual notice of the dangerous activity, constituted a breach of its duty of care owed to Plaintiff and his Minor Child.
Luoni v. Berube, 431 Mass. 729 (2000).support_reasoning: The proposition assumes that a defendant with actual notice of dangerous activity who fails to take reasonable steps thereby breaches a duty of care. Luoni v. Berube holds the opposite in the context of social hosts and guest‑supplied fireworks: the court finds that the homeowners had no duty to control or stop the dangerous activity because they did not provide, control, or create the risk, despite their awareness of the fireworks. Thus, the case rejects imposing a duty in these circumstances and does not support the claimed proposition.
Luoni v. Berube, 431 Mass. 729 (2000).relevant_excerpt: “The Appeals Court…concluded that the teenage host was not liable because he had neither provided the firecrackers nor controlled the making of the pipe bomb…we…agree…because…the defendants did not provide the harmful item, did not control its use, and did not create the situation that caused the danger.… The defendants did not furnish the fireworks or give permission for the display on their property. Their status as social hosts carried with it neither the means, nor the legal obligation, to supervise or prevent the discharge of the fireworks by others.”

Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.raw_text: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc., 408 Mass. 355 (1990)
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.proposition: The injuries suffered by the Minor Child were a natural and probable consequence of Defendant’s negligent supervision and would not have occurred but for Defendant’s breach of duty.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.case_name: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.support_reasoning: The opinion is about dram shop liability and clarifies that statutory violations are only some evidence of negligence and causation must still be proven. The court ultimately finds that the plaintiff failed to prove negligence (and expresses doubt about causation), and reverses the judgment for the plaintiff. It does not hold that the injuries were a natural and probable consequence of the defendant’s conduct or that they would not have occurred but for the defendant’s breach; it concludes the opposite on these core negligence elements.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.relevant_excerpt: “Any liability on the defendant's part in such a situation must be grounded in the common law of negligence… meaning that the plaintiff has the burden of proving each and every element of that claim: duty, breach of duty… causation (actual and proximate) and damages… Of the seventeen special verdict questions… only question seven addressed this element of negligence. The jury answered, ‘No’… Since the jury thus answered, it follows that the plaintiff had failed to prove negligence. Therefore, the judgment for the plaintiff cannot stand.”

Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.raw_text: Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc., 423 Mass. 637 (1996)
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.proposition: The injuries suffered by the Minor Child were a natural and probable consequence of Defendant’s negligent supervision and would not have occurred but for Defendant’s breach of duty.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.support_reasoning: The quoted concurring opinion states that the facts do *not* warrant a finding that the plaintiff’s injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by the defendant’s negligence. That is the opposite of the claimed proposition that the injuries were a natural and probable consequence of the defendant’s negligent supervision and would not have occurred but for the breach. Thus, this case, at least in the cited passage, rejects foreseeability and causation on these facts rather than supporting them.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.relevant_excerpt: "I concur in the view that ‘[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiffs injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence.’ Ante at 640-641."

Remy v. MacDonald, 440 Mass. 675 (2004).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, children are considered particularly vulnerable, and entities that undertake to supervise and care for children are held to a standard of reasonable care commensurate with that undertaking.
Remy v. MacDonald, 440 Mass. 675 (2004).support_reasoning: The opinion is focused on whether a pregnant woman owes a legal duty in negligence to her unborn child and ultimately declines to recognize such a duty. It does not discuss entities that undertake supervision or care of children, nor does it articulate any general principle that children are particularly vulnerable warranting a heightened or context-specific standard of care. The case instead draws a bright-line limitation on tort liability in the prenatal context, rather than expanding or defining duties owed to children by caregivers or supervisors.
Remy v. MacDonald, 440 Mass. 675 (2004).relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that there are inherent and important differences between a fetus, in utero, and a child already born, that permits a bright line to be drawn around the zone of potential tort liability of one who is still biologically joined to an injured plaintiff.”

Dias v. Brigham Med. Assoc., Inc., 438 M.raw_text: Dias v. Brigham Med. Assoc., Inc., 438 Mass. 317 (2002)
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assoc., Inc., 438 M.proposition: Defendant is vicariously liable for the negligent acts and omissions of its employees, agents, and servants under the doctrine of respondeat superior.
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assoc., Inc., 438 M.case_name: Dias v. Brigham Medical Associates, Inc.
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assoc., Inc., 438 M.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that traditional respondeat superior applies to a medical practice corporation for the negligent acts of its physician employee, without requiring proof that the corporation controlled specific treatment decisions. The court explains that once an employer‑employee relationship is established, the employer is vicariously liable for torts committed within the scope of employment. This directly supports the proposition that a defendant employer can be vicariously liable for the negligent acts and omissions of its employees under respondeat superior.
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assoc., Inc., 438 M.relevant_excerpt: “Because we conclude that traditional respondeat superior liability applies to the employer of a physician, and that to establish such liability it is not necessary that the employer have the right or ability to control the specific treatment decisions of a physician-employee, we vacate the judgment and remand the case… To prevail against BMA, the plaintiffs need only establish that (1) at the time of the alleged negligence Dr. Schlitzer was an employee of BMA, and (2) the alleged negligent treatment… occurred within the scope of Dr. Schlitzer’s employment by BMA.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85K.proposition: As a direct and proximate result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff, as parent of the Minor Child, has incurred and will continue to incur medical and related expenses for the care and treatment of the Minor Child in an amount presently estimated at approximately Three Thousand Five Hundred Dollars ($3,500.00), exclusive of future medical and related costs.

McCann v. Middleborough, 1 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: McCann v. Middleborough, 1 Mass. App. Ct. 811 (1973) (rescript)
McCann v. Middleborough, 1 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, parents are entitled to recover medical expenses incurred on behalf of their minor children as a result of another’s negligence.
McCann v. Middleborough, 1 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns whether governmental immunity shields a municipality operating a public hospital from tort liability. It does not discuss, analyze, or decide anything about a parent’s right to recover medical expenses incurred for an injured minor child. The reference to the father’s “consequential damages” count is purely descriptive and the court resolves the case solely on immunity grounds, not on the scope of recoverable damages or parents’ rights to such expenses.
McCann v. Middleborough, 1 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: "This is an action of tort brought by Michael C. Gerber, ppa. and his father, Robert J. Gerber against the city of Worcester alleging in one count that the city was negligent in caring for the minor plaintiff while he was a patient in the Worcester City Hospital operated by the defendant and in another count that the father sustained consequential damages as a result of the injury to his son. Demurrers to these two counts were sustained. … While both parties argue the question of the application of charitable immunity, the only issue which appears on the face of the declaration is whether governmental immunity protects the city from liability."

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85A.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, parents are entitled to recover medical expenses incurred on behalf of their minor children as a result of another’s negligence.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Award Plaintiff pre‑judgment and post‑judgment interest as allowed by law, including pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B;
